channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: United Nations Says Food Aid Will Be Restored
item.description: In a statement, the World Food Program, the main United Nations anti-hunger agency, said $675 million pledged would allow it to “fully reinstate” the reduced aid.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Utilities Cautioned About Potential for a Cyberattack After Ukraine’s
item.description: Working remotely, attackers conducted “extensive reconnaissance” of the Ukraine power system’s networks, stole the credentials of operators and learned how to switch off the breakers, plunging more than 225,000 Ukrainians into darkness.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: After Gains Against ISIS, Pentagon Focuses on Mosul
item.description: The United States military is laying groundwork for a fight to retake Iraq’s second-largest city, moving to isolate it from the Islamic State’s headquarters in Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers during an exercise in January with American and Spanish trainers southeast of Baghdad.

item.title: Argentina Reaches Deal With Hedge Funds Over Debt
item.description: The funds declared legal war on Argentina 12 years ago, refusing to partake in the country’s restructurings after it defaulted on $100 billion of debt in 2001.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: Louis Lanzano for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This is a giant step forward in this long-running litigation,” Daniel A. Pollack, the court-appointed mediator, said on Monday. But, he added, it is “not the final step.”

item.title: New Study Links Zika Virus to Temporary Paralysis
item.description: Mosquito-borne Zika virus may lead to increased risk of Guillain-Barré syndrome, which leaves patients unable to move and in some cases requires life support.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS
item.media:description: Xiojanni Badillo embraced her aunt, Daysi Mendoza, who was recovering from Guillain-Barré syndrome at the Erasmo Meoz Hospital in Cucuta, Colombia.

item.title: Violence Erupts in Greece as Migrants Try to Cross Into Macedonia
item.description: Less than a week after a meeting to discuss stemming the flow of people toward Germany, thousands were stuck in Greece after the Macedonian authorities sealed the border.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and DIMITRIS BOUNIAS

item.title: Australian Inquiry Puts a Top Aide to Pope on the Defensive
item.description: Cardinal George Pell, chosen by Francis to spearhead Vatican financial reform, is testifying voluntarily before a Royal Commission looking into child sexual abuse.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Cardinal George Pell speaking on Monday via video link from Rome.

item.title: Iranian President and Moderates Make Strong Gains in Elections
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani and his allies seem to have run strongly in voting for Parliament and Iran’s clerical panel, though official results are pending.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A poster of the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, who led moderates to a sweep of parliamentary seats in Tehran.

item.title: Parents of American Held in North Korea Unable to Speak with Him
item.description: In their first comment on the arrest, the parents of Otto F. Warmbier said they hoped North Korea would free him after he admitted stealing a political banner.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier on Monday apologized on North Korean state television in Pyongyang.

item.title: Sikh Soldier Sues Defense Dept., Citing Religious Discrimination
item.description: Capt. Simratpal Singh, a decorated West Point graduate, said the Army had singled him out for special tests because of his beard and turban.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.media:description: Capt. Simratpal Singh said he had been targeted because of his religious beliefs.

item.title: Parents of American Held in North Korea Unable to Speak with Him
item.description: In their first comment on the arrest, the parents of Otto F. Warmbier said they hoped North Korea would free him after he admitted stealing a political banner.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier on Monday apologized on North Korean state television in Pyongyang.

item.title: France Faces Protests as It Dismantles ‘Jungle’ Migrant Camp
item.description: Some migrants lit shacks on fire to protest their evictions as workers tore down tents and disassembled huts at the camp near Calais.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Some migrants lit shacks on fire on Monday to protest their eviction from “the Jungle,” a camp near Calais, France.

item.title: Hope and Fear Await a Basque Leader on His Release From Prison
item.description: The release of Arnaldo Otegi — jailed for his ties to an outlawed political party — and what it might mean for the Basque cause is raising alarm in Spain.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Arnaldo Otegi, a leader of the Basque separatist movement, during his arrest in San Sebastián, Spain, in 2009.

item.title: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe’s Birthday Is Rife With Political Jockeying
item.description: The visible frailty of President Robert G. Mugabe has focused attention on the increasingly fierce struggle within his party to succeed him.
item.dc:creator: HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO and NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Mugabe’s birthday cake during celebrations at the Great Zimbabwe historic site in Masvingo on Saturday.

item.title: Riots Erupt on Greek Border
item.description: Conflict on the border with Macedonia surged as the Greek government warned that as many as 70,000 people could be trapped in the country within a month.

item.title: Indictments Over Fukushima Disaster
item.description: The indictment of former TEPCO executives over the Fukushima nuclear plant meltdown in 2011 will be a great encouragement to the victims, the leader of an activist group said.

item.title: Narendra Modi Struggles to Fulfill His Plan to Rejuvenate India
item.description: The prime minister’s pledge to revitalize the economy and create a deluge of jobs has become subsumed in political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in New Delhi in January. His promise to create jobs for the one million people who enter India’s work force each month has become subsumed in political turmoil.

item.title: Death Toll Rises to 38 in IS Bombing at Iraqi Funeral
item.description: The death toll has risen to 38 after an IS suicide bomber struck an Iraqi funeral Monday, wounding dozens in a crowded reception room. A local Shiite militia leader is among the dead in a town north of Baghdad that saw a wave of revenge attacks after a similar bombing in January.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pakistan Braces for Violence After Execution of Governor’s Killer
item.description: Security forces were put on high alert in major cities across the country after the hanging of Malik Mumtaz Hussain Qadri, who killed Salmaan Taseer, an advocate for changes in blasphemy laws.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: The body of Mr. Qadri, who was hanged at 4:30 a.m. on Monday at the Adiala Jail, a high-security prison in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

item.title: IHT Retrospective Blog: 1916: Kaiser’s Goal Is Verdun
item.description: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German newspaper reports that the Kaiser’s goal is Verdun in 1916.
item.dc:creator: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
